head.title: Greenhouse Effect Culprit May Be Family Car

hedline.hl1: Greenhouse Effect Culprit May Be Family Car

block.p: Although I agree wholeheartedly with the major premise of ''The Greenhouse Effect? Real Enough'' (editorial, June 23), I also feel that two positions you take need refinement and emphasis: (1) ''Develop cheaper, safer nuclear power.'' I can support this suggestion provided that
* a Federal blue-ribbon body is created to set standards and for enforcement;
* the French modular standard is incorporated in power-plant design, and the German graphite impregnation method is used in preparing nuclear fuel,

* and a foolproof, environmentally acceptable method of nuclear waste disposal is developed. (2) ''Encourage conservation of energy.'' Unfortunately, you do not mention this country's greatest source of air pollution, the internal combustion engine, which powers all our private automobiles and intercity trucks and aircraft.

The No. 1 air polluter in North America is the private automobile, not the coal-fired power plant, as you and others imply. The automobile consumes almost 45 percent of all the petroleum used in our country every year. The British thermal unit value of this consumption, almost three billion barrels of oil annually, is far greater than that consumed by coal-fired power plants. The internal combustion engine's waste products are mainly oxide gases of carbon and nitrogen, plus water vapor. They contribute more than 50 percent to the carbon dioxide content of the air and the acid in acid rain!

In addition, inter-city trucks consume about 8 percent of our oil every year, producing fewer but similar oxides of carbon per B.T.U. of energy produced, and the jet engine does the same thing, especially on takeoff, using about 7 percent of our annual oil consumption.
So, if anything is to be accomplished in controlling the greenhouse effect, plus acid rain, plus smog, petroleum use in transportation will have to be materially reduced.

Proper employment of rail mass transit and rail freight can accomplish this reduction in the burning of fossil fuel, especially oil. Air quality can be further improved by electric motive power and non-fossil-fuel power generation. JACK BRANNAN Pittsburgh, July 12, 1988 The writer is a transportation systems consultant.
